notes: Educational summaries. Simplified; phrased as 'commonly involved in'.
disclaimer: Educational summary (simplified). Not medical advice; not clinical diagnosis.

Heschl_L.title: Heschl's gyrus (Left)
Heschl_L.summary: Contains primary auditory cortex. It supports early cortical processing of sound features like frequency and timing, before higher-order areas interpret meaning. Often engaged by tones, speech, and music.

Heschl_R.title: Heschl's gyrus (Right)
Heschl_R.summary: Contains primary auditory cortex. It supports early cortical processing of sound features like frequency and timing, before higher-order areas interpret meaning. Often engaged by tones, speech, and music.

Temporal_Sup_L.title: Superior temporal gyrus (Left)
Temporal_Sup_L.summary: Auditory association cortex that helps analyze complex sounds, including speech. In many people, the left superior temporal region is strongly involved in language comprehension. It often works with frontal language areas during listening.

Temporal_Sup_R.title: Superior temporal gyrus (Right)
Temporal_Sup_R.summary: Auditory association cortex that helps analyze complex sounds. The right superior temporal region is often associated with prosody and aspects of music perception, though roles vary by task and person. It collaborates with broader attention and memory systems during listening.

Postcentral_L.title: Postcentral gyrus (Left) — primary somatosensory cortex
Postcentral_L.summary: Primary somatosensory cortex for the body (touch, vibration, proprioception). It maps the opposite (right) side of the body in an orderly 'homunculus-like' organization. Often engaged by tactile stimulation and pain-related input.

Postcentral_R.title: Postcentral gyrus (Right) — primary somatosensory cortex
Postcentral_R.summary: Primary somatosensory cortex for the body (touch, vibration, proprioception). It maps the opposite (left) side of the body in an orderly 'homunculus-like' organization. Often engaged by tactile stimulation and pain-related input.

Precentral_L.title: Precentral gyrus (Left) — primary motor cortex
Precentral_L.summary: Primary motor cortex involved in initiating voluntary movement. It contains a body map and primarily influences the opposite (right) side of the body. Often engaged during finger tapping, speech motor planning, and other motor tasks.

Precentral_R.title: Precentral gyrus (Right) — primary motor cortex
Precentral_R.summary: Primary motor cortex involved in initiating voluntary movement. It contains a body map and primarily influences the opposite (left) side of the body. Often engaged during finger tapping and other motor tasks.

Insula_L.title: Insula (Left)
Insula_L.summary: Integrates internal body-state signals ('interoception') with emotional and cognitive context. Commonly involved in pain, nausea/disgust, and awareness of bodily arousal. Often treated as part of a broader salience system that helps prioritize attention.

Insula_R.title: Insula (Right)
Insula_R.summary: Integrates internal body-state signals ('interoception') with emotional and cognitive context. Commonly involved in pain, nausea/disgust, and awareness of bodily arousal. Often treated as part of a broader salience system that helps prioritize attention.

Cingulum_Ant_L.title: Anterior cingulate cortex (Left)
Cingulum_Ant_L.summary: Often involved in attention, conflict monitoring, and error detection. Frequently linked to the affective/motivational component of pain and effortful control. Works with frontal and insular regions during demanding or emotionally salient situations.

Cingulum_Ant_R.title: Anterior cingulate cortex (Right)
Cingulum_Ant_R.summary: Often involved in attention, conflict monitoring, and error detection. Frequently linked to the affective/motivational component of pain and effortful control. Works with frontal and insular regions during demanding or emotionally salient situations.

Amygdala_L.title: Amygdala (Left)
Amygdala_L.summary: Helps detect biologically relevant salience, especially threat and uncertainty. Supports fear learning and can modulate memory systems so emotionally important events are remembered more strongly. Often engaged during threat-related stimuli and emotional faces tasks.

Amygdala_R.title: Amygdala (Right)
Amygdala_R.summary: Helps detect biologically relevant salience, especially threat and uncertainty. Supports fear learning and can modulate memory systems so emotionally important events are remembered more strongly. Often engaged during threat-related stimuli and emotional faces tasks.

Hippocampus_L.title: Hippocampus (Left)
Hippocampus_L.summary: Supports formation of episodic memories and the binding of context (what happened, where, and when). Important for learning new facts and experiences. Dysfunction is commonly associated with memory impairment.

Hippocampus_R.title: Hippocampus (Right)
Hippocampus_R.summary: Supports formation of episodic memories and the binding of context (what happened, where, and when). Often associated with spatial/contextual aspects of memory, though roles vary. Dysfunction is commonly associated with memory impairment.

Thalamus_L.title: Thalamus (Left)
Thalamus_L.summary: A major relay and gating hub for sensory and motor information on the way to cortex. Helps regulate arousal, attention, and the 'broadcasting' of signals to cortical networks. Often involved broadly across many tasks rather than one narrow function.

Thalamus_R.title: Thalamus (Right)
Thalamus_R.summary: A major relay and gating hub for sensory and motor information on the way to cortex. Helps regulate arousal, attention, and the 'broadcasting' of signals to cortical networks. Often involved broadly across many tasks rather than one narrow function.

Frontal_Orb_Med_L.title: Medial orbitofrontal / ventromedial prefrontal (Left)
Frontal_Orb_Med_L.summary: Commonly involved in valuation: assessing how rewarding or meaningful something is. Helps integrate emotion, memory, and goals to guide decisions. Often active in reward, preference, and social decision tasks.

Frontal_Orb_Med_R.title: Medial orbitofrontal / ventromedial prefrontal (Right)
Frontal_Orb_Med_R.summary: Commonly involved in valuation: assessing how rewarding or meaningful something is. Helps integrate emotion, memory, and goals to guide decisions. Often active in reward, preference, and social decision tasks.

Calcarine_L.title: Calcarine cortex (Left) — primary visual cortex (V1)
Calcarine_L.summary: Primary visual cortex involved in early processing of visual input. It contains a retinotopic map (neighboring neurons represent neighboring points in visual space). Often strongly activated by simple visual stimuli like flashing checkerboards.

Calcarine_R.title: Calcarine cortex (Right) — primary visual cortex (V1)
Calcarine_R.summary: Primary visual cortex involved in early processing of visual input. It contains a retinotopic map (neighboring neurons represent neighboring points in visual space). Often strongly activated by simple visual stimuli like flashing checkerboards.

Precuneus_L.title: Precuneus (Left)
Precuneus_L.summary: A medial parietal region often associated with visuospatial imagery and self-referential processing. Frequently discussed as part of the default mode network. Engagement depends strongly on task and mental state.

Precuneus_R.title: Precuneus (Right)
Precuneus_R.summary: A medial parietal region often associated with visuospatial imagery and self-referential processing. Frequently discussed as part of the default mode network. Engagement depends strongly on task and mental state.
